title: Democrats Lean Toward Dropping Clean-Electricity Plan
summary: Sen. Joe Manchin is opposed to the proposal, which would push utilities to draw more power from clean-energy sources. WASHINGTON-A $150 billion program aimed at pushing utilities to draw more power from clean-energy sources is in danger of falling out of Democrats' social-policy and climate bill, according to people familiar with the negotiations, as Sen. Joe Manchin (D., W.Va.) remains opposed to the provision.

title: U.S. Offers Payments to Families of Afghans Killed in August Drone Strike
summary: State Department to support slain aid worker's family's effort to relocate to U.S., Pentagon says. WASHINGTON-The U.S. has offered payments to the families of Afghans killed in a drone strike in the waning days of the war in Afghanistan and is supporting one family's efforts to relocate to the U.S., the Pentagon said Friday.

title: Ex-Boeing Pilot Charged in Crash Probe Is Scapegoat, Lawyer Says
summary: Prosecutors face challenges in pinning the blame for deception of air-safety regulators on a lone employee, legal observers say. The former Boeing Co. employee charged with misleading air-safety regulators about a flight-control system that played a significant role in two deadly 737 MAX crashes is being unfairly blamed for the disasters, his attorney said.

title: Netflix Fires Employee Who Leaked Information About Dave Chappelle Special
summary: Move comes as streaming giant faces employee backlash over stand-up show that some said was offensive to transgender community. Netflix Inc . fired an employee who it said had leaked confidential financial information about the streaming giant's controversial Dave Chappelle stand-up comedy special "The Closer" to Bloomberg News, the company said Friday.

title: Biden Says Witnesses Who Defy Jan. 6 Panel's Subpoenas Should Be Prosecuted
summary: House Democrats are seeking contempt of Congress charge against former Trump aide Steve Bannon. WASHINGTON-President Biden said Friday that witnesses who defy subpoenas from a House panel investigating the Jan. 6 assault on the U.S. Capitol should be prosecuted, contradicting White House assertions that those decisions would be made independently by the Justice Department.

title: China Evergrande Spillover Risks Can Be Controlled, Central Bank Says
summary: Developer had blindly diversified and expanded, official says, but the risk exposure of individual financial institutions to the developer isn't big. China's central bank sought to ease concern about potential contagion from China Evergrande Group 's debt crisis, saying the risk of the developer's problems spilling over into the financial system was controllable.

title: Fatal Stabbing of British Lawmaker David Amess Called a Terrorist Attack
summary: Islamist extremism could be a motive, police said; 25-year-old man arrested on suspicion of murder. LONDON-A man fatally stabbed a British lawmaker during a meeting with constituents in an assault U.K. authorities called a terrorist attack.

title: 'The French Connection': Mainlining Raw Realism
summary: William Friedkin's 1971 film ramped up Hollywood's traditional formula of the "procedural" crime movie with a free-wheeling, no-holds-barred style of acting and cinematography. Fifty years ago this month, William Friedkin's "The French Connection" set a new benchmark for crime thrillers. The production was budgeted initially at $2 million by Twentieth Century-Fox. This was reduced to $1.5 million at a time of exigency for the studio, and Mr. Friedkin recalls on the 2009 Blu-ray disc from Fox that the film finally cost $1.8 million. It grossed more than $51 million in the U.S., and in the following spring won five Academy Awards, including Best Picture.

title: Chicago Mayor, Police Union Take Vaccine Fight to Court
summary: Mayor Lori Lightfoot and the local Fraternal Order of Police are at odds over city requirement to report vaccination status. CHICAGO-Mayor Lori Lightfoot and the local Fraternal Order of Police on Friday said they had filed competing motions for injunctions against each other, escalating a fight over Chicago's vaccination policy.

title: ProShares Readies Bitcoin ETF for Launch
summary: Firm is slated to be the first to roll out an exchange-traded fund based on bitcoin futures. ProShares is ready to roll out the first U.S.-listed bitcoin exchange-traded fund.

title: Bank of America, Netflix, Moderna: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. Wall Street pocketed more gains from a speedy rebound in the U.S. economy. Banks are releasing the billions of dollars they put away to prepare for a wave of loan defaults during the pandemic recession. Bank of America's third-quarter profit rose 58% from a year earlier, aided by $1.1 billion in loan-loss reserves. Banks' lending businesses were in a slump despite the improving U.S. economy. Bank of America shares gained 4.5% Thursday.

title: White House Commission on Changing Supreme Court Airs Differences
summary: In first public hearing, legal scholars and jurists argue over whether Congress has the right to increase or otherwise alter the high court's composition. WASHINGTON-President Biden's Supreme Court commission split sharply Friday over increasing the number of justices, with some members questioning whether Congress held the power to do so and others arguing that expansion could be the only way to redress what some liberals cast as the court's unfairly conservative bias.

title: Biden Suddenly Loves Frackers
summary: After waging war on the industry, Biden wants its help to reduce gas prices.. Falling poll numbers concentrate the presidential mind, and the result can be startling. Look no further than this nominee for headline of the year from Politico this week: "Biden team asks oil industry for help to tame gas prices."

title: Kelly Services Names CIO to Boost Job-Placement Tech
summary: Veteran IT leader Rosie Rivel will help the staffing firm increase the use of digital tools as employers scramble to fill jobs. Staffing firm Kelly Services Inc. has named a veteran risk-and-compliance leader as chief information officer, aiming to boost recruiting software and other digital tools as employers struggle to refill jobs in the aftermath of the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Big Government Isn't Popular Again
summary: Gallup finds a decline in public support for more taxes and services.. If President Biden wants to understand why his $3.5 trillion entitlement spending plan is stalled in Congress, he might look at the new poll from Gallup. Asked whether government should do more or less to solve the country's problems, 52% of Americans said government is doing too much.

title: Captain Kirk vs. Prince William
summary: Actor William Shatner replies to a royal critic of his rocket flight.. William Shatner of "Star Trek" fame didn't see any Klingons or Romulans during his recent trip to outer space, but he's now firing a few photon torpedoes at another enemy of the whole enterprise. This week Britain's Prince William, without mentioning any names, told a BBC interviewer: "We need some of the world's greatest brains and minds fixed on trying to repair this planet, not trying to find the next place to go and live."

title: Japan's Coming Defense Buildup
summary: With China in mind, Tokyo vows to double military spending.. Japan's new Prime Minister Fumio Kishida dissolved the lower house of Parliament Thursday, setting elections for Oct. 31. The contest will focus on the pandemic and economy, but the most notable proposal from Mr. Kishida's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) may be its pledge to double defense spending.

title: Parkland School Shooting Suspect Is Expected to Plead Guilty
summary: Cruz could still face death penalty for shooting that killed 17 students and staff members. Attorneys for the former student accused of killing 17 students and staff members in the 2018 school shooting in Parkland, Fla., said he planned to change his plea, likely indicating he would plead guilty to murder charges.

title: Goldman Sachs's Petershill, a Collection of Private-Equity Stakes, Slides After IPO
summary: Petershill Partners is down 9% since its lackluster debut in London last month. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. specializes in taking companies public. It is having a tougher time with one closer to home.

title: Toy Executive Pushed Industry to Be Big-Screen Powerhouse
summary: Brian Goldner, who died at age 58, persuaded Hollywood that Transformers and other Hasbro brands could be bigger entertainment properties. Brian Goldner believed toys should have a leading role in Hollywood.

title: Politico's New Owner Plans to Grow Staff, Launch Paywall
summary: Axel Springer, whose $1 billion acquisition of Politico is expected to close next week, also eyes foreign-language editions. BERLIN-Axel Springer SE plans to eventually put Politico's content behind a paywall and immediately boost the political-news publisher's head count by more than 10% once the German conglomerate's $1 billion deal to buy the company closes, expected next week.

title: J.B. Hunt Expects Strong Freight Demand to Extend Into 2022
summary: Bellwether for transportation industry says labor shortages and congestion are constraining the sector. Freight bellwether J.B. Hunt Transport Services Inc. expects bottlenecks at West Coast ports to intensify heading into the holidays, with congestion continuing to snarl labor-strapped logistics networks and strong shipping demand extending into 2022.

title: As Inflation Rises, Beware of the Money Illusion. It May Cost You a Lot.
summary: People often focus on the actual amount of money they earn or spend, rather than its purchasing power. As inflation rises in the U.S., a blind spot known as the money illusion could lead many people to make serious financial mistakes.

title: Covid Anxiety Is a Health Problem Too
summary: A new study finds 129 million additional cases of major mental disorders world-wide compared with pre-pandemic figures.. In New York City, I often see people walking down the sidewalk, masks hanging low over their chins, looking fearful and dodging one another. The health benefit from these wary rituals is minimal to nonexistent, and they illustrate the toll that fear of Covid-19 has taken on mental health.

title: There's No Good Answer to the 737 MAX Disaster
summary: A grand jury faults one executive's serious error of omission, but the larger mystery is unsolved.. With the indictment of a former Boeing employee in the two 737 MAX crashes that killed 346, have we finally got to the bottom of a colossal industrial screwup? No. As persuasive as the indictment might be, it doesn't try to persuade that the crashes were caused by Mark Forkner, who served as chief technical pilot for the 737 MAX.

title: Notable & Quotable: Humor
summary: 'If you don't know why that's funny, then you're not the audience for the joke.. The Atlantic's Emma Green interviewing Kyle Mann, editor in chief of the satirical website Babylon Bee, Oct. 14:

summary: 'America is thirsty to reward grace and virtue,' the Woodson Center's retiring president says. 'There's going to be a revival coming soon.'. Washington

summary: Wall Street firm's investment bankers had their second-best quarter on record. Companies are ravenous for deals. Wall Street investment bankers are feasting on big paydays.

title: Gas Crisis Prompts Fresh Proposals From EU
summary: European governments must address immediate price rises, say officials in Brussels. The European Union is considering new measures, including joint purchases of gas to build up the bloc's strategic reserves, to help alleviate future energy crises like one the continent now faces.

title: Capitol Police Officer Charged With Obstruction Related to Jan. 6 Riot
summary: Michael Riley allegedly told a contact on Facebook to delete posts showing that the person was at the Capitol. WASHINGTON-A 25-year veteran of the U.S. Capitol Police force was arrested Friday and accused of urging a man who participated in the Jan. 6 riot to cover his tracks on social media, authorities said.

title: Stocks Close Best Week in Months After Strong Earnings Reports
summary: Dow industrials climb more than 1% as oil prices extend run-up. U.S. stocks rose Friday, notching their biggest weekly gains in months following a strong streak of earnings reports.

title: Moderna Vaccine for Adolescents Delayed for FDA Review
summary: Agency holds off decision on expanding use of shot to 12-to-17-year-olds while it looks into risk of rare heart condition. The Food and Drug Administration is delaying a decision on authorizing Moderna Inc.'s Covid-19 vaccine for adolescents to assess whether the shot may lead to heightened risk of a rare inflammatory heart condition, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: La Niña Weather Pattern Could Prolong Drought in Southwest
summary: Lesser-know counterpart to El Niño brings drier, warmer winters to Southern U.S., cooler winters to the north. For the second year in a row, the weather phenomenon La Niña is expected to alter the U.S. winter.

title: Read My Lips! (Saturday Crossword, October 16)
Spell Weaving (Saturday Variety Puzzle, October 16)
Oat Rally Hits Records Amid Drought
summary: Severe dry weather hurts supply, driving up prices for breakfast staple and alternative-milk ingredient. Drought has roiled power markets and lifted lumber prices. Now it is hitting breakfast.

title: In Season 3 of 'Succession,' Jeremy Strong Lets Kendall Roy Off the Leash
summary: The HBO drama is back, picking up the saga of billionaire Logan Roy and the blood sport for control of Waystar Royco. Kendall Roy is holed up in a bathroom. Lying fully clothed in an empty bathtub, having chucked his family's media empire into a buzz saw on live TV.

title: Suspected Ransomware Payments Nearly Doubled This Year, Treasury Says
summary: Financial firms flagged nearly $600 million in suspected ransomware payments; Treasury investigators identified billions more. WASHINGTON-The volume of suspected ransomware payments flagged by U.S. banks has surged this year, on pace to nearly double last year's, the Treasury Department said Friday, highlighting the scale of a problem that governments across the world have described as a critical national security threat.

title: Meret Oppenheim's Lifelong Experiments
summary: Starting as a Surrealist in the 1930s, the artist spent half a century making edgy, experimental work.. In early 1936, Meret Oppenheim covered an inexpensive porcelain teacup, saucer and spoon with "a bit of fur that I had purchased once at random," as she later recalled. When the work she entitled "Object" appeared that May in a Surrealist exhibition in Paris, and later at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the 23-year-old artist became an instant star of the international avant-garde.

title: Ed Beauvais Helped Reshape U.S. Airline Industry
summary: America West Airlines founder started three carriers and planted the seeds for what became the largest in the world, American Airlines. Ed Beauvais had a not-so-secret tactic to rally the Little League team he coached for his sons, blasting Jerry Reed's "When You're Hot, You're Hot" before games.

title: J&J Covid-19 Booster Shot Endorsed by FDA Advisers
summary: The experts, whose recommendations are often followed by the FDA, said the agency should clear the extra dose for adults. Advisers to the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously Friday to recommend the agency authorize an extra dose of Johnson & Johnson 's Covid-19 vaccine, to shore up protection against the coronavirus.

title: Indocency on Display at the Art Institute of Chicago
summary: The museum fired all its volunteer greeters and guides because most were white women with above average means.. The Art Institute of Chicago crouches on Michigan Avenue, defending the surrounding Grant Park from the city's skyscrapers crowding in. Spreading over more than a million square feet, the museum has almost 300,000 works of art. And zero docents.

title: Come to Miami for Sunshine, Low Taxes-and Normal Life
summary: Move Silicon Valley to Florida, an investor said. 'How can I help?' asked Mayor Francis X. Suarez.. Miami

title: Alisal Fire in Santa Barbara County Is 41% Contained
summary: Highway 101 reopens; evacuation orders and warnings remain in effect. Firefighters gained more control of the Alisal Fire burning in Santa Barbara County, as part of a Southern California highway reopened. But gusty, shifting winds could threaten further progress over the weekend.

title: Tether Hit With $41 Million Fine in Latest Crypto Crackdown
summary: Regulator says company misrepresented dollar reserves behind its digital tokens; Tether said issues have since been addressed. WASHINGTON-Tether Ltd., the largest stablecoin issuer, agreed to pay a federal regulator a $41 million penalty Friday, the latest result of the Biden administration's broader crackdown on cryptocurrency markets.

title: Covid and the Abuse of Scientific Authority
summary: 'Follow the science'? Show me the data.. Kudos to Gary Saul Morson for "Partisan Science in America" (op-ed, Oct. 12) and to David Klein for his accompanying illustration of scientists chained to a politician in groupthink. As a trained virologist and practicing neuroscientist, I am appalled at the scientific and political censorship regarding Covid-19 immunization.

title: Young Progressives Lead Where Biden Falters
summary: The left is aggressive while the president is not at the top of his game.. Have we failed the youngest generations of our citizens? The radical progressive movement ("Progressives Hold the Capital Captive" by Peggy Noonan, Declarations, Oct. 9) is in large part the domain of young, entitled people who have been coddled before they have made their first contribution to society. They heap scorn on their country, using modern norms to judge the actions of those who lived by their wits, character and strength in times past-times in which the young progressives would have been found wanting.

title: Occam's Razor, Meet Hickam's Dictum
summary: In medicine, the simplest and most logical diagnosis is usually correct. But not always.. Regarding Andrew Crumey's review of "Life Is Simple" (Books, Oct. 9): Occam's razor has wide applicability to the practice of medicine. The simplest and most logical diagnosis is usually correct. This principle of logic is used to narrow diagnostic possibilities.

title: Gaps in Sanctions Let Iran Grow Stronger
summary: Businesses can help by knowing their customers' customers.. Iran's advancements in drone technology are a strategic threat to the U.S. and its allies ("Iranian Drones Reshape Mideast Security," World News, Oct. 7). Gaps in sanctions are partially to blame for Iran's strengthened capabilities. The business community, too, shoulders a measure of responsibility. To stymie Iran's efforts, the U.S. should expand sanctions on Iran's drone program, and businesses should adopt enhanced-due-diligence and know-your-customer's-customer practices. This would reduce the risk of commercial products being used to surveil and attack innocent civilians and U.S. forces.

title: Gifted Programs and the Path to Fairness
summary: Rather than cancel the game, try to create a level playing field.. Regarding "Bill de Blasio's Parting Gift" (Review & Outlook, Oct. 9): Don't lower the water, raise the bridge. The claim is that gifted-and-talented programs are unfair because wealthier parents pay for tutoring to aid their children's entry, keeping some minorities out. But rather than kill the highly successful program, New York should make it more accessible by offering tutoring and after-school educational assistance to all. Rather than cancel the game, try to create a level playing field.

title: LinkedIn Social Network Is Leaving China, but Microsoft Remains
summary: Software giant will have to navigate rising restrictions in China as it looks for growth for Bing, Teams and cloud. Microsoft Corp. is shutting down LinkedIn in China following increased regulatory scrutiny, but the software giant has other businesses still exposed in the important market.

title: A Fall Weekend Getaway in the Pacific Northwest-Easy and Gorgeous
summary: Resume Subscription. THE COLUMBIA RIVER, which delineates the border between Oregon and Washington state is set in a gorge of surpassing drama and beauty. It's the result of a little-known period of American geo-history, when the glacial ice-melt in prehistoric Lake Missoula periodically sent walls of water up to 1,000 feet high and moving at 60 miles an hour along the path that's now the Columbia. Portlanders seeking a recreational getaway have long made the area a destination, particularly the town of Hood River which, thanks to high winds, is one of the world's best spots for kiteboarding, kite-surfing and the new trend of winging.

title: DOJ to Ask Supreme Court to Block Texas Abortion Law
summary: Biden administration's move presents high court with new occasion to consider the state's novel ban on women's abortions after six weeks. WASHINGTON-The Justice Department on Friday said it would soon file a request with the Supreme Court seeking to block enforcement of a Texas law that bans many abortions in the state.

title: Retail Sales Rise, Showing Resilient U.S. Consumers
summary: Supply constraints raise questions about approaching holiday-shopping season. Americans stepped up their spending in September, a sign of resilient demand and rising inflation as consumers head into the holiday shopping season.

title: How Malaria Brought Down Great Empires
summary: A mosquito-borne parasite has impoverished nations and stopped armies in their tracks. Historian Amanda Foreman searches the past for the origins of today's world. Read previous columns here.

title: Goldman Sachs Has the Recipe for Long-Term Gains
summary: Bank's huge returns in deal making might not be sustainable forever, but across-the-board improvements to its overall business bode well. As the autumnal poem goes, nothing gold can stay. Except maybe Goldman Sachs shares.

title: Italy Implements Tough Covid-19 Requirements for Workers
summary: Employees must provide proof of vaccination, negative test or recent coronavirus infection to access workplaces. ROME-Italians returned to their workplaces Friday needing to show proof that they have received a Covid-19 vaccine, tested negative or recovered from the virus, a policy that has touched off protests and could provide a preview of a similar mandate planned by the Biden administration.

title: Fears Grow for Fate of Lebanon's Capital
summary: Resume Subscription. BEIRUT-Hussein Hamdar sat in the backyard of his building in the shade of a tree and stared at the wall facing him. Forty-five years ago, his grandfather was killed on the other side of the barrier during Lebanon's civil war, shot in the head by a sniper as he was performing his prayers.

title: What to Read This Week
summary: The enormous world of Edward O. Wilson, the problem of Vichy, a painter of power, Noël Coward's genius and more..

title: No More Trillions
summary: More evidence the economy doesn't need another massive federal intervention.. President Joe Biden likes to pretend that his pending multitrillion-dollar plan to restructure the U.S. economy will cost nothing. Of course he's not telling the truth. But nothing seems to be exactly what the economy needs from Washington right now. In fact, this morning's retail sales report suggests that perhaps Washington's recent binge of debt-fueled federal spending and Federal Reserve money creation should have stopped several trillions ago.

title: U.S. to Lift Restrictions for International Travelers
summary: European allies have been pressing Biden administration to lift Covid-19 travel restrictions. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration plans to lift travel restrictions for international travelers to the U.S. on Nov. 8, the White House said Friday.

title: America's Workers Are Leaving Jobs in Record Numbers
summary: U.S. workers handed in nearly 20 million resignations this spring and summer. This year's bold career move is walking out the door.

title: Chinese Man Who Killed Ex-Wife as She Was Livestreaming Is Sentenced to Death
summary: The killing drew attention to a lack of protection for Chinese women trying to leave abusive marriages. A murder case involving a woman killed a year ago by her ex-husband while she was livestreaming landed in the spotlight again as a Chinese court sentenced the man to death.

title: Chinese Telecom Giant ZTE in Dispute With U.S. Court-Appointed Monitor
summary: Dallas lawyer has threatened to use friendship with judge to get longer term in lucrative monitorship, people familiar with the matter say. WASHINGTON-China's ZTE Corp. in 2017 agreed to the oversight of an independent monitor when it pleaded guilty to Justice Department charges of illegally exporting sensitive U.S. technologies to Iran and repeatedly lying to investigators.

title: Novelist Elizabeth Strout Never Judges Her Characters
summary: The Pulitzer prize-winning writer returns to the story of Lucy Barton in her new book.. Growing up on a dirt road in Maine, in a home without newspapers, magazines or television, Elizabeth Strout often felt like she had been born in the wrong place. A self-described chatterbox in a family of few words, she longed for spaces that bustled with humanity. "I was desperate to be around other people," she says. When she first arrived in New York City in the early 1980s, she recalls thinking, "Oh wow! This is it."

title: Biden Administration to Revive Remain-in-Mexico Immigration Policy
summary: The decision to resume the Trump-era policy by mid-November abides by a federal judge's order. The Biden administration is preparing by mid-November to resume a Trump-era immigration policy of returning migrants to Mexico while their requests for asylum in the U.S. are considered, the administration said in a last-minute court filing to comply with a federal court order.

title: Effort to Bar Tech Companies From 'Self-Preferencing' Gains Traction
summary: Bipartisan legislation announced in the Senate Thursday aims to stop tech companies from favoring their own products. WASHINGTON-Legislation to bar internet companies from favoring their own products on their platforms is gaining more support, in what could be a potential threat to the business models of tech giants like Amazon.com Inc. and Apple Inc.

title: Adele Created '30' During a Divorce. Others Have Chronicled Breakups in Song.
summary: From Marvin Gaye to Kacey Musgraves, records that follow romantic splits can be poignant and memorable works of art. Adele teased her coming album, "30," with Thursday's release of the single "Easy on Me."

title: Biden Presses Climate Agenda on Wall Street
summary: White House lays out finance-related initiatives ahead of U.N. summit on climate change in Glasgow. WASHINGTON-Calling climate change a systemic risk to the financial system, the White House released a report Friday outlining its strategy for new rules that could affect investment disclosures, insurance policies and home loans.

title: Palm Beach Home on the Water to List for $84.9 Million
summary: Fund manager Jerry Jordan of Hellman, Jordan to sell six-bedroom home with dock. Fund manager Gerald "Jerry" Jordan and his wife, Darlene Jordan, are listing their waterfront mansion in Palm Beach for $84.9 million, making it one of the most expensive homes for sale on the island.

title: 'Halloween Kills' Star Jamie Lee Curtis on Why She 'Loathes' Being Scared
summary: A queen of the horror genre, the actress talked to us about 'MacGyvering' a podcast studio, her love of mid-century furniture-and her inconvenient aversion to fear. EARLY IN THE new movie "Halloween Kills," Laurie Strobe-Jamie Lee Curtis's now-iconic character-is in the back of a truck, on the way to the hospital, terrified, a stab wound in her abdomen, fresh from setting fire to a house with the masked monster Michael Myers inside of it. She sees a fire truck heading toward the conflagration and screams: "Let it burn!"

title: Bitcoin Price Hits $60,000 Ahead of Potential ETF Approval
summary: Securities and Exchange Commission could rule on proposals for bitcoin-futures fund as soon as next week. Bitcoin hit $60,000 Friday for the first time since April, as traders anticipate U.S. regulators will approve the first exchange-traded fund to track the cryptocurrency.

title: Heroic American Shoppers Braved High Prices, Low Inventory
summary: Key variable for retail sales going into the holidays seems to be the state of Covid-19 rather than what is on the shelves and how much it costs. Shortages are making it harder and more expensive for Americans to find what they want to buy. That didn't stop them in September.

title: Starwood Capital Rakes in $10 Billion for Distressed Real-Estate Deals
summary: Firm has already deployed $3.5 billion from the fund, CEO Barry Sternlicht said. Starwood Capital Group has hauled in more than $10 billion for its latest pool to invest in distressed real estate such as hotels, office buildings and residential housing.

title: A New Way to Tackle This Market Moment
summary: Stocks are sky-high and bond yields are near zero. A strategy called 'return stacking' can free up part of your portfolio to put to work in a quieter part of the investing world.. When there's nowhere to run, nowhere to hide, what do you do?

title: What You Should Expect From a Financial Adviser
summary: They can be expensive. So it's crucial that you know what kind of help you should be getting from them.. I plan to retire in a few years, and I would like to begin working with a financial adviser. I recognize that fees for financial planning can be steep. My questions: What services should I look for from an adviser? Or, put another way, what services should I expect for my money?

title: Why We Choose to Suffer
summary: In the search for a meaningful life, simply seeking pleasure isn't enough. We need struggle and sacrifice.. When life is going well, we can forget how vulnerable we are. But reminders are everywhere. There is always the possibility of pain-a sudden ache in the lower back, a cracked shin, the slow emergence of a throbbing headache. Or emotional distress, such as realizing that you just used Reply All to reveal an intimate secret. Such examples only touch the surface. There is seemingly no limit to the misery we can experience, often at the hands of others.

title: Where Will Wally the Wandering Walrus End Up?
summary: Resume Subscription. This summer, marine researchers were presented with an unexpected problem. How, exactly, do you get a 2,000-pound juvenile walrus to cut short his tour around Europe and swim back home to the Arctic?

title: The Ant Man's World: 'Edward O. Wilson' and 'Scientist'
summary: The researcher and writer who has made the world of social insects his life's work has also become their interpreter.. A well-known portrait of Edward Osborne Wilson shows the smiling Harvard professor hovering, like a benevolent god, over some models of his cherished leafcutter ants. The photograph serves as the cover of "Tales From the Ant World," Mr. Wilson's most recent and, by my count, 35th book. The large ant right beneath Mr. Wilson's chin, a mix of Mars Rover and de Chirico mannequin, wields a leaf almost as big as the entomologist's head. The proportions seem off, but in a larger sense they really aren't: As Mr. Wilson, now in his 90s, has reminded us over a long, distinguished career, ants can more than hold their own against humans. There are, by some rough estimates, 10,000 trillion ants in the world at any given moment, and their combined weight (Mr. Wilson, who likes to mock his ineptness at math, nevertheless supplies numbers whenever he can) would match the total weight of the planet's human population.

title: 'The King's Painter: Holbein's Portraits of Power
summary: Combining the material and the ethereal, Hans Holbein brought a haunted quality to pictures with a political edge.. We trust that political art is always bad art, but Hans Holbein the Younger, one of the first masters of the modern character study, was a political artist to the tip of his brush. He was also, as Franny Moyle shows in this intricate and enlightening study of Holbein and his age, a religious artist about whom we know very little.

title: 'Noël Coward on (and in) Theatre' Review: The Charm Offense
summary: A polymath with a high-velocity pen, Coward masked exactitude with effervescence.. The young Noël Coward was often disparaged as a boy who was clever and knew it. You have to admire his response: "How do they think I could be clever and not know it?" The logic and tone are distinctively Coward's. Here was confidence and reasonableness and a nimble wit able to render ambition and even arrogance appealing. And, obviously, a dramatic flair for turnabout.

title: Fiction: 'Eight Dogs' and 'Search History'
summary: A swashbuckling epic from 19th-century Japan and an unsettling story of an AI-dominated tomorrow.. Serialized in Japan between 1814 and 1842 and totaling 180 chapters, Kyokutei Bakin's novel "Nansō Satomi Hakkenden" is, in the words of its translator, Glynne Walley, "one of the longest sustained narratives in the world." Mr. Walley, a professor of Japanese literature at the University of Oregon, has taken up the task of bringing this megillah to English-language readers under the title "Eight Dogs, or 'Hakkenden.' " But patience must be counseled: This first volume, "An Ill-Considered Jest,"contains 14 chapters-not even 10% of the whole.

title: Federal Judges or Their Brokers Traded Stocks of Litigants During Cases
summary: Resume Subscription. Mary Geiger Lewis acquired Walmart Inc. stock. Charles Norgle Sr. reported nearly a dozen buys and sells of Pfizer Inc. shares. Charles Siragusa had two accounts that bought Medtronic PLC stock.

title: 'When France Fell' Review: The Problem of Vichy
summary: In 1940, American isolationists wanted Marshal Pétain's government to be treated as neutral. The British thought otherwise.. Almost 50 years ago, Robert Paxton published his influential "Vichy France: Old Guard and New Order, 1940-1944." The book awakened readers to the shock of how close France came to becoming an authoritarian nation. It also introduced many people to the strange regime-officially called the État français but still referred to today as Vichy France-that continues to resonate in the collective memory of that important nation. (Vichy was the town in central France from which the new regime governed.)

title: Children's Books: 'Ferryman' Review
summary: In the opening volume of Claire McFall's trilogy, a mysterious fate and a fantastic voyage.. In the stunned aftermath of a train crash, a 16-year-old Scottish girl named Dylan stumbles out of a railway tunnel into a bleak landscape. While she's trying to get her bearings, and wondering why she can't hear any sirens, she notices a teenage boy waiting at a distance. His expression is cold and disinterested, his attitude scornful. Yet soon he orders her to come with him. Dylan, bewildered, finds herself obeying. Thus begins "Ferryman," the first volume of an internationally bestselling romantic-fantasy trilogy by Claire McFall.

title: A Selfish Case for a Trillion-Dollar Coin
summary: It may not be practical for the economy. But it would be very fun to use to buy orange soda. Every time the U.S. confronts a government impasse over spending, there's a fanciful proposal to mint a trillion-dollar coin to avoid a debt ceiling and a shutdown.

title: Virgin Galactic, Bitcoin, Moderna, Goldman: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Virgin Galactic shares were on a descent trajectory; Backing for Moderna's booster gave the stock a shot in the arm. Wall Street indexes opened higher, putting stocks on course for gains at the end of a choppy week. Here's what's moving in Friday's trading:

title: Lawyers for Ex-Officer to Argue Shooting Death 'Innocent Mistake'
summary: Kimberly Potter, a 26-year veteran, shot Mr. Wright with 9mm handgun while saying 'I'll tase ya'. The killing of Daunte Wright by former Brooklyn Center, Minn., police officer Kimberly Potter was an innocent mistake, lawyers for the officer argued in a recent court filing.

title: Where to Go Stargazing, Whether Your Budget Is $95 or $95,000
summary: This fall is high time to get starry-eyed. Five astronomy-focused getaways, from a low-key adventure in North Carolina's Outer Banks to a 'Sky's the Limit' package in California's Wine Country. IT'S BEEN A banner year and a half for astronomy buffs. Backyard hobbyists, housebound for much of the pandemic, drove sales of home telescopes, according to David Nagler, president of Tele Vue Optics in Chester, N.Y., which specializes in astronomical instruments. "There isn't a week that doesn't contain several phone calls from customers who either bought their first telescope or had a latent interest in amateur astronomy but never got around to pursuing it," said Mr. Nagler. And then this July, the Shanghai Astronomy Museum-the world's largest-opened and the Chankillo Astronomical Complex, a prehistoric observatory in Peru's Casma Valley, was added to the Unesco World Heritage List.

title: Five Best: Stories of Friendship
summary: Selected by Derek B. Miller, the author, most recently, of the novel 'How to Find Your Way in the Dark.'. By John Irving (1989)

title: Inflation Sets Off Alarms Around the World
summary: The big question for the global economy: Will price rises feed further inflation cycles?. Rising inflation is triggering anxiety around the world as a surge in demand following the easing of Covid-19 lockdowns has been confronted by supply bottlenecks and rising prices of energy and raw materials.

title: Why Ford Picked Tennessee for Its New Electric-Vehicle Plant
summary: State leaders and the Tennessee Valley Authority offered millions of dollars in incentives, inexpensive and reliable energy. Tennessee is emerging as a leader in a national scramble to develop electric-vehicle and battery production, as states compete to woo multibillion-dollar investments from auto companies pivoting away from the combustion engine.

title: The Most Valuable Quarterback in College Football Might Ride the Bench
summary: In the new era where college athletes can make money, Oklahoma's Spencer Rattler may be the most marketable player regardless of whether he starts. Oklahoma quarterback Spencer Rattler is the face of Raising Cane's chicken tenders. He owns a Ram pickup truck and a sporty Dodge sedan as part of an endorsement deal with a local car dealership. He even has an online store that sells T-shirts and hoodies emblazoned with his custom logo-his initials and his jersey number tipped with the fangs and tail of a rattlesnake.

title: At Times Like These, Inflation Isn't All Bad
summary: Inflation might be part of the solution for an economy undergoing a complex transition. The jump in inflation that the Covid crisis has brought on might not be as transitory as many have hoped. But for the economy to smoothly adjust to a post-pandemic future, higher prices could be necessary.

title: Walmart, With Eyes on Amazon, Tries to Build a Fintech Startup
summary: Former Goldman executives look to marry their expertise with retailer's consumers and data to offer financial services. Walmart Inc. is building a new weapon in its war with Amazon.com Inc. : a fintech startup.

title: Dubai Halts Air-Cargo Imports Amid Supply-Chain Snags
summary: Local backlog represents another bottleneck in a world filling up with them. Dubai's main cargo handler said it would stop accepting most imports of airfreight arriving at the emirate's main airport as it rushes to reduce a backlog that has snarled processing and delivery of goods across the United Arab Emirates.

title: Mookie Betts Is a Superstar Rarity in the MLB Playoffs
summary: While most of the sport's biggest names missed the postseason, the Dodgers outfielder helped power the Dodgers to the NLCS. By squeaking past the San Francisco Giants and advancing to the National League Championship Series, the Los Angeles Dodgers gave Major League Baseball something that otherwise would have been suspiciously absent from this postseason: a legitimate superstar playing deep into October.

title: Largest Cities Had Some of the Lowest U.S. Inflation Rates
summary: New York City, Los Angeles and Chicago were below the national level while rural areas grappled with increases in gasoline and vehicle prices. The consumer-price index, which measures what consumers pay for goods and services, rose 5.4% in September from a year earlier. Rising energy prices, supply-chain disruptions and an increase in spending have led to higher inflation across the country. While prices rose across the board for the year ended last month, the degree of change varied among different geographic regions and populations. Among the metropolitan areas surveyed, the largest and most urban places had some of the lowest price increases. Chicago saw an increase of 4.5%, and in the New York City area there was a 3.8% increase. The Northeast region's rate was nearly a percentage point below the overall national level.

title: Do Covid-19 Vaccines Belong on TV? Hollywood Can't Decide
summary: From the thriller 'You' to medical dramas such as 'New Amsterdam,' vaccination is proving to be tricky territory. The newest season of the Netflix thriller "You" has a timely plot point: vaccines.

title: EA's Hot Season of Discontent
summary: Videogame publisher heads into anticipated record holiday season with questions hanging over two of its biggest franchises. On the cusp of what should be its merriest holiday season yet, Electronic Arts has found a few lumps of coal in its stocking.

title: Data Concerns Drag Down U.S.-Listed Chinese Brokers
summary: Shares in Futu and Up Fintech fall sharply, after Chinese state media says new privacy laws would pose challenges to them. Shares in Futu Holdings Ltd. and Up Fintech Holding Ltd. fell sharply, after Chinese state media said the country's tough new data-privacy laws would pose challenges for the brokerage firms.

title: China's Robinhoods Could Be Next in Beijing's Crosshairs
summary: Beijing's rising concerns about data security-and overseas listings-put China's previously highflying online brokers at risk. China's regulatory crackdown has already slowed trading flows for its Robinhood-like online brokers. Now data security is a new problem. And tougher enforcement of existing rules on cross-border investment on top of all that could add up to an existential threat for these brokers.

title: Facebook Should Clarify Terms of Service, Irish Privacy Regulator Says
summary: Draft ruling calls for fine but supports company's view that terms of service are adequate for gaining users' permission to analyze data. A draft ruling from Ireland's privacy regulator would require Facebook Inc. to change how it informs users about its data processing but disregards complaints that the social-media giant needs to obtain direct consent for its activities.

title: Democrats Rely on Big Guns as Early Voting Plummets in Virginia
summary: Crucial governor's race pits Democrat Terry McAuliffe against Republican Glenn Youngkin.

title: Trading Furor Complicates White House Decisions on Fed Leadership
summary: Questionable trading activities by two Fed officials cast cloud over Jerome Powell's path to reappointment. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's chances for a second term leading the central bank so far have been dented but not derailed by a reputational crisis over stock-trading disclosures by senior officials.

title: How YouTube Makes Sure Its Hitmakers Don't Stumble
summary: The site has spent more than a decade building an in-house agency for digital superstars, drawing ad sales, sponsorships and other revenue. When online comedian Adande Thorne met with his YouTube adviser last year, the feedback was blunt: His new videos weren't working.

title: Is Your Flooded Basement Tax Deductible? Congress Will Decide
summary: Lots of Americans have suffered property damage from fires, storms and winter freezes this year. More generous write-offs for losses may be on the way.. If you've had property damage from a disaster like a fire or flood this year, will the losses be tax deductible? For millions of Americans, the answer depends on what Congress does in the next few months.

title: LVMH Sends Mixed Signals on Chinese Luxury Spending
summary: Strong sales are reassuring but give a muddy picture of what is happening since Beijing's crackdown on the superrich. Aspirational consumers across the world continue to snap up Louis Vuitton handbags in record numbers. But the latest results from the brand's owner, LVMH, didn't give investors all the answers they wanted.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
